title.narrative: Justica nos Trilhos - Apoio a terceiros EU/CPL grant

description.narrative:
This project aims to promote alternatives to the mining and agribusiness development model in Maranhao, strengthening agroecological family farming and food sovereignty. It will support 41 families in three farming communities in Acailandia, Maranhao, with a focus on women and young people, and will address three main problems: 1) lack of community control of their territory, including accelerated loss of areas to monoculture agribusiness by sale or leasing of areas of land; 2) weak community organisation, with little incentive to generate agricultural income and small-scale cooperatives/business; 3) lack of inclusion of young people and women in agricultural production, increasing food insecurity. Key activities include: participatory community mapping of three communities following the methodology of “Cartografia Social da Amazônia” (Social Mapping of the Amazon), community training on agroecological production and commercialisation, and creation of a rotating community-based micro-credit fund.
Monoculture soy and eucalyptus plantations in Maranhão, Brazilian Amazon, has weakened community organisation in agrarian reform settlements, especially those cut off by the Carajás Railway (for transportation of iron ore mined to export to China). Agribusiness companies are attempting to lease or illegally purchase farming communities' land, either through finance or pressure and threats. In 2020, the Maranhão State Government launched the Ecological Economic Zoning of the Amazon region of Maranhão, which reduces the percentage of forest preservation (Legal Reserve) of properties in the biome from 80% to 50%. This is yet another incentive for deforestation and the rush to acquire new areas due to a projected sharp rise in land prices. In addition, the pressure of aerial spraying of pesticides, which often completely destroys farmers' fields, has led to increasing poverty, food insecurity and environmental destruction.
